South America, East, South and West Africa,

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: NEJD SUCCESSION DISPUTE.
div.p: The "Morning Post's" Berlin correspondent writes that German advices from Constantinople state that the death of Ibn-el Rsachid, the Sultan of Nejd, which was reported some six weeks ago, is now officially confirmed. According to the "Frankfurter Zeitung," the Porte is fitting out twenty-six battalions, which are to be taken from the first and second levies of the Macedonian Rodifs, for an expedition to the Sultanate of Nejd in the hope of securing the succession to the son of Ibn-el-Raschid and protecting him from the aspirations of Muberek, the Sheikh of Koweit. The expedition will be under the command of Pertev Pachs, who is, described as one of General von der Golte's most brilliant pupils. Pertev Pachs, who acted as Turkish Attaché at the Japanese headquarters during the great war, has taken up his quartere in Bagdad.

The circumstance that Mubarok is regarded as an agent of Great Britain explains the interest which the announcement of the action contemplated by the Porte arouses in Germany. It has always been imagined in Germany that Great Britain, by supporting Mubarek against the Sultan of Nejd, has committed a grave political mistake, but it is feared that the death of Ibn-el-Raschid may now place an entirely different aspect upon affairs in Central Arabia and result in Mubarek definitely gaining the upper hand in a quarter of the world which, embracing as it does the future terminus of the Bagdad Railway, possesses a peculiar interest for Germany.

The "Vossisobe Zsitang" asserts that descendants of the Dynasty of Ibn Saud, which reigned in Nejd before the time of Ibn-el-Raachid, are living in Koweit and India, and it is anxious to know if it is the intention of the British, in the event of Mubarak being victorious, to instal one of them Saltan in Nejd. It supposes not, but observes that they will doubtless be used as pawns in the struggle for supremacy in Central Arabia.

In the determination of the Porte to fight for the son of Ibn-el-Raschid, the Liberal organ places little hope. Three years ago, it observes, the Turkish Government, after sending a gunboat to Koweit and ordering the despatch thither of a large detachment of troops from Bagdad, beat a hasty retreat in view of the threatening attitude of the British authorities, and it, therefore, doubts if in the present instance Pertev Pasha will ever be permitted to advance so far as Nejd.

We doubt whether the British Government takes the slightest interest in Nejd, always provided that the status quo is respected at Koweit. It really makes no difference whether an Ibn Raschid, an Ibn Sand, or Turkish Pasha roles at Hail or Riadh as long as no attempt is made to seize the port of entry to Mesopotamia and Central Arabia. Our contemporary the "Vossische Zeitung" apparently forgets that Abdel Aziz ibn Saui is the right ful heir to, as he is the actual ruler of the greater part of the Nejd, and Great Britain is unlikely to make confusion worse confounded by adding another to the list of Emirs and Chieftains whose struggles in the wastes of Arabia seem as constant and as purposeless as the battles of the kites and crows.

div.p: We are requested to state that, contrary to the announcement made last Sunday, the services will not be changed at present.

div.head: Fatal Tramway Accident
div.p: A native boy of 13 was run over by a tramcar near Gabbari yesterday and killed. His body was removed to hospital, and the driver arrested.

div.head: Elementary Education Certificate
div.p: of the 3,389 pupils of the native schools who have undergone the recent examination, only 904 were successful in obtaining the Elementary Education certificate.

div.head: Bandman Opera Company
div.p: Friends of Mr. Maurice E. Bandmann in Egypt will be pleased to learn that his opera company has been meeting with great success in Japan. According to the "Japan Advertiser," the largest audience ever assembled in the history of Yokohama public hall greeted the initial performance of the company, and so crowded were the houses on the subsequent evenings that Mr. Bandmann wag induced to considerably extend his stay. Mr. Harry Cole, the clever comedian, continues to be the life and soul of the company. He is described by a local, paper as "the greatest comedian that ever visited the East."

div.head: Father's Tragic Death
div.p: Having received information yesterday that a young native, living at Hadra, had beaten his father to death, the police authorities promptly appeared on the scene and opened an inquiry. The evidence showed that the son, who is only 15 years of age, fell into a violent rage while giving some food to his two little Brothers. The father, an old man of 68, scolded him and the boy ran from the house. The father picked up a stone and attempted to throw it at him, but failed and fell down dead. The body was sent to hospital for a post mortem examination, which showed that the death of the old man, who was found slightly wounded in the neck, was due to some internal disease, probably heart failure.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. C. de Mansfeld Findlay, British Charge d'Affaires, and the personnel of the British Agency are now installed for the summer at Maison Chataway, Bulkeley.

Major John Edward Pine-Coffin, D.S.O., one of the officers injured in the attack by natives at Denishwai, is the Squire of Porteldge, in Devonshire, which manor has been owned by his family for four centuries.

The Coffins were prominent folks in Devonshire as early as the reign of King John. One of the line, Sir William Coffin, Kt, of Portledge, was a notable character at the Court of Henry VIII. As Master of the Horse he figured in the coronation ceremonial of the luckless Anne Boleyn. When he died Sir William left to King Henry his best horses and hawks:

In 1766 the male line failed, and the estate was inherited by the Rev. John Pine, grandson of a daughter of the house of Coffin, who by royal license assumed that surname in addition to his own. Since then the Squires of Portledge have been Pine-Coffin.
The King of Siam has conferred the Order of the Clown of Siam ou M. d'Abazs, Russian Conso in Alexandria.

div.head:
DENISHWAI AGAIN.
MORE QUESTIONS IN PARLIAMENT.
FEELING OF SATISFACTION.

div.p: The Foreign Secretary, Sir Edward Grey, in replying to questions by some irresponsible Radical Members in the House of Commons last night, has created a general feeling of satisfaction throughout England as showing the Government's appreciation of the situation in Egypt and its determination to support the authorities in Egypt in the maintenance of law and order with all the forces at their command.

"Al Moayad" states that the British Government has formally requested the Egyptian Government to despatch to England all the official documents in the Danishwai Case; and the Ministry of the Interior has translated these papers and submitted them to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which will forward them to the Foreign Office.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir,-The attempt of a small section of the House of Commons to obtain the intervention of the Secretary for Foreign Affairs for the commutation of the sentence of death upon the four leaders of the dastardly outrage against British officers at Denishwai is exceedingly regrettable, as are also the opinions which were so freely expressed in the Lobby by a few. It is, of course, well-known to all Britishers in this country that Mr. Dillon and his followers are but governed by unruly impulses of the moment, and we also have the assurance of the home Press that the sentences were universally approved. We, at any rate, recognize such interference as ill. timed and would only regard it as an unjustified effort by an insignificant party, were it not that it will have its ill effect upon the country. A grossly exaggerated account, enlarging upon the sympathy which the great ruling power of England has for the fellaheen in their action, will be disseminated through the provinces by a certain section of the vernacular Press, and will persuade the villagers that their comrades of Danishwai are regarded by the English public as having had great provocation and have suffered unduly for their impetuous rashness. They will be led to believe that the English officer is their enemy and regards them as his slave, and that British justice in Egypt is a thing of the past.

It is our duty, therefore, and the duty of our Press to emphasize the support which the authorities in Egypt have received from the home Government in the matter and to impress upon the Egyptian public the horror with which the news of the outrage was received in Great Britain. We must point out that England has accepted the sentences as severe, but is, convinced of the justice thereof. and is prepared to agree to even sterner measures in the event of any similar occurrence in future, I am, etc.

As an example of the attitude of a section of the native Press we publish to-day, with notes and comments, selections from an article entitled "The Last Word as to the Denishwai Trial and Judgment," published in "Al Moayad:"

"The affair is a simple one and may be summed up as follows:- The people of Denishwai did not seek the officers in their camp, but the officers went to their village, Denishwai, to shoot their pigeons in and around their 'girns.' (They had warned the village of their intention and received no intimation that their arrival would be resented.) Reading between the lines it is clear that the people of Danishwai had been annoyed (!) by the shooting of their pigeons on a previous occasion. They were therefore likely to be annoyed by this repetition of the offense by the same offenders (!) It may perhaps therefore be admitted that they prepared to act on the first movement of the offenders, but it is impossible to admit the charge of evil premeditation on their part considering that their action was to depend upon that of others upon whom the real and sole responsibility should be laid.
"We may admit therefore that.
(1) The people failed to moderate their opposition to their aggressors (Failed to moderate is an ingenious description of an assault of a most cowardly and brutal character upon unresisting men.)
(2) They did not confine their action to preventing them continuing the aggression. (Too true !)
(3) They were not content with taking their guns by way of indemnity. (The guns were given them by Major Pine-Coffin's or lers).

"Moreover they are more to blame than their attenders because they did not seek redress by legal means but defended their rights by a gross aggression, which was all the grosser that he was made against officers of the army of occupation. Armies of occupation have in all countries rights based upon force and maintained by force only. The responsibility of the people was increased by the death of one of the officers happening a few hours after the incident and by two others being dangerously wounded."

Our contemporary then criticizes the constitution of the Special Court, which it asserts was not, required in this case. That is a matter of opinion, and not of fact, and we shall therefore refrain from discussing the question. The fact that a strong guard of troops was kept round or near the courthouse is severely commented. In our opinion the presence of the troops, so far from influencing the judges, as our contemporary, oddly enough, suggests, was necessary to avoid the risk of the court being, "influenced" by the hostile demonstrations of relatives of the accused. Our contemporary continues by blaming the presence of the British Advisors of the Ministries of the Interior and Finance at the trial. They would have been blameworthy bad they lightly absented themselves from what was, from the point of view of any high official, a very important and interesting case. The advisers, we are assured, are "representatives of the British Occupation". In what sense pray? Not officially, for they rank as Egyptian officials just as the Armenian Nubar Pasha or the Frenchman Suleiman Pasha.

Our contemporary next attacks Helbawi Bey, who, as an ex-Nationalist, gets no quarter, and then makes certain remarks about the pigeons, which it declares constitute real property, the shooting of which is prohibited by English law as an act of theft. But the question arises here a question which our contemporary does not attempt to solve whether "beladi" pigeons can be said to be the property of any individual. Birds that migrate as do the beladi pigeons from one district to another are surely in no sense "domestic." "Al Moayad" also declares that Egyptian law classes it among the offences that can be resisted by all possible means. Does our contemporary affirm that if A. sees B. firing at pigeons that he believes are his, he has a right to shoot B. or to attempt to break his head with blows of a nabout?
Finally we have a prophetic but inaccurate description of the execution. It is, to put matters plainly, a tissue of inaccuracies. We should like to state that:
1. That the men condemned to death were prevented from witnessing the flogging of other prisoners, the doors to their tents being turned in the opposite direction.

2. That they were hanged in presence of their women and children when all accounts concur in stating that the women and children, and indeed all the inhabitants of Danishwai, were kept within the village at a distance of some hundred yards.

We should also like to remind our contemporary that when Moslems of the "varnished" class, the class which drinks cognac and haunts cafés, were heard in Cairo on the night after the Denishwai affair became known, drinking toasts in honour of the murderers of Capt. Bull, it was a little unwise to assume, as our contemporary has done, that the whole population of Egypt disapproved most heartily of the attack, etc., etc., and regarded the whole affair as a sad misunderstanding. In response to numerous applications for the issues of the "Egyptian Gazette" containing the report of the Denishwai trial, we may state that these issues are now out of print.

div.head: ATTACK ON BRITISH SOLDIER
div.p: An unpleasant incident is reported from the neighborhood of Mex, a British soldier, Pte. O'Brien, of the 2nd Royal Dublin Fusiliers, having been brutally assaulted while returning to camp at Dekhileh to the west of Mex.

At about midnight on Monday be was riding back to camp on a donkey and had reached point near the station when he was attacked by three men who set upon him and not finding any money (which the soldier carried in his boot) beat him and kicked him in the abdomen in the most brutal fashion and then made off, on hearing the approach of some persons.

The donkey boy of course took to his heels and the injured man made the best of his way back to camp. He did not report the incident till next day, when finding himself very weak and in great pain he demanded to be admitted to hospital.
His injuries are severe, double hernia having been produced by the kicks he received and will require at least three weeks' medical treatment.
The police have been successful in capturing two of the Arabs involved; the arrest of the third will probably be announced in the course of the day.

We do not consider that this attack has any importance beyond that of any other crime of violence. Soldiers returning to Mex camp have been more than once robbed in the past, and in our opinion this long and rather lonely road ought to be patrolled be two or three mounted policemen.

div.head: DREDGER FOR ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Messrs. Wa. Simons and Co. (Limited), of Renfrew, launched from their yard a few days ago, complete and ready for work, a powerful twin-screw stern-wheel 1000-ton hopper dredger which they have constructed to order of the Egyptian Government for the improvement of the port of Alexandria. The bucket ladder, which is constructed of the best form of cinder work in accordance with the builders' latest practice, is designed for dredging to A depth of 40 feet below water level. Owing to the varied nature of the material to be dredged at Alexandria, two sets of buckets are provided, one set of large cubic capacity for raising free material and one set of smaller buckets of exceptional strength and special design for rock dredging. The dredger is propelled at eight knots speed by two sets of compound surface condensing engines, each driving its own propeller, steam being supplied by two steel multi-tubular boilers constructed to Lloyd's requirements for 120lb. working pressure. The dredger, which is named the Cleopatra, has been built to the requirements of the British Admiralty under the direction of Colonel Raban, Director of Works, Admiralty, assisted by Lieutenant John P. James and Engineer-Commander W. D. Chop", who have acted as resident Admiralty overseers over the boil, engines, and boilers respectively.

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S NEW DECORATION.
APPRECIATIONS OF HOME PRESS.
div.p: The conferment of the Order of Marit upon the Barl of Cromer bas been cordially welcomed at home, and the Government are congratulated by the press generally for this prompt recognition of his further splendid services in Egypt. The following are a few of the leading newspaper comments:

div.head: "TIMES."
div.p: Perhaps the most unexpected" item in the list is that which heads it-the bestowal of the Order of Merit upon Lord Cromer. There is nothing inappropriate in the selection, for there is no Order of any kind which Lord Cromor's name would not adorn. But the fact that the Order of Merit was understood to be confined to persons eminent in science, literature, or art, and to those who had won distinction in the fighting services, is bound to excite some curiosity as to Lord Cromer's claim. It the Government wanted a technical defence, they might fairly say that in honouring Lord Cromer's great administrative services they were honouring an extraordinarily successful application of the scientific method to practical affairs; while have not his annual reports been for years the most engrossing and widely-read pages in our official literature. The public will be agreed, however, that where it is a question of honouring Lord Cromer no excuses are necessary.

div.head: "DAILY NEWS."
div.p: The highest honour in the gift of the King —that of the Order of Merit has been bestowed upon Lord Cromer. The greatest of all modern Empire builders, he stands as the one man, unstained by the smudge of-financial interests, or the taint of ambition and notoriety bunting, who has ruled a dependency in wholehearted devotion to the welfare of the inhabitants.

div.head: "PALL MALL GAZETTE."
div.p: Lord Cromer's appointment to the Order of Merit is wholly felicitous, for no one has vindicated the governing talent of his countrymen to their greater honour, and his work in Egypt has long since raised itself above the level of controversy. Promotions to the Order of Merit will always invite severe scrutiny, but Lord Cromer's place in the exclusive circle is beyond cavil.

div.head: ""GLOBE."
div.p: Lord Cromer enters the jealously guarded portals of the Order of Merit: there are few living Englishman who have deserved better of their country, who we achieved more solid work, or who have sustained the national prestige at a higher pitch in the eyes of foreign nations.

div.head: "WESTMINISTER GAZETTE."
div.p: The Birthday Honours List is at once very lengthy and interesting. Lord Cromer is given the Order of Merit, a very high distinction amply earned by very great services.

div.head: "TRIBUNE."
div.p: Lord Cromer, who, in addition to the many honours that have been bestowed upon him in recognition of his services in Egypt, is to-day admitted to the charmed circle of the Order of Merit, brings the number of that very select coterie up to fifteen. He is the seventh member of the much-coveted distination, the others baing Earl Roberts, Viscount Wolseley, and Lords Kitchener, Rayleigh, Kelvin, and Lister. The only representative of the Lower Chamber is, as is well known, Mr. John Morley.

div.head: IMPERIAL OTTOMAN BANK
div.p: In the absence of Lord Hillingdon, the Earl of Bessborough presided over the annual meeting of the company of the above name at Winchester House, London, last week. The accounts showed net profits of £464,200, and a dividend of 16s, per share, was agreed to. The Chairman said that the report would be regarded by the shareholders as quite satisfactory. From an agricultural point of view the year 1905 had been favorable. Certain lines of railway had seen their receipts augmented, and the total of the kilometrical guarantees paid by the Government was diminished by £T.57,448. He was pleased to state that their relations with the Imperial Government continued satisfactory. The arrangement for the service of the Macedonian treasury, commenced in March 1905, centralized in the hands of the bank the responsibilities of the three vilayets. Their activity in the provinces had had during the year 1905 a very considerable enlargement arising not only from the creation of several sub-agencies but also from the marked development in the position of these agencies. The deposits of the public continued to show a considerable increase, notwithstanding the competition of new banks, which were allowing higher rates of interest than theirs. - The report was adopted, and a statutory resolution was carried prolonging the existence of the company.

div.head: EGYPTIAN HOTELS. EFFECT OF THE GENERAL PROSPERITY ON THE COMPANY.
div.p: The ninth annual general meeting of the Egyptian Hotels, Ltd., was held on the 26th June at the registered offices of the company, 11, Ironmonger-Jane, London, BC, Lord Cloud Hamilton (Chairman of the company) presiding. The notice issued by the Secretaries (Messrs.

W. B. Pest and Co.) having been read by Mr. Pent and also the report of the auditors, The Chairman said: Gentlemen, -The accounts in your hands show a financial position stronger than the most sanguine could have anticipated. The steady flow of prosperity which has marked Egypt for some years has continued with increased force, and no doubt can be entertained that additional hotel accommodation will be required. You will see that steps have been taken to provide this in order to retain our hold on the visitors to Cairo. The construction of the Assouan dam has contributed to an increase in the value of agricultural land, while the British capital freely invested in this, and industrial and other ventures, is an evidence that the British occupation will be permanent. The knowledge of this has produced a sense of security hitherto unknown in Egypt and has given a stimulus to trade and the investment of capital by Europeans, as well as by native landowners, whose wealth had been previously, hoarded up to avoid the consequences apprehended from the uncertain political conditions formerly existing. Their economic changes have affected both the takings of our hotels and the value of our property.
SALES OF SURPLUS LAND

Our land at Ghezireh has risen enormously in value, and, as indicated in the director's report, we have sold our surplus land at Ghezireh at a price far greater than we over expected, which, we hope, will enable us within a comparatively short period to pay off our debentures. The service of the debentures at present costs £13,305 per annum, by which amount the shareholders will benefit when all the debentures are paid off. In this connection, I might mention that in the early stages of this rise in the value of land the Board gave Mr. Baehler, their general manager, an option for the sale of all the surplus land at Ghezireb at a price that would have realized about £100,000. Subsequently, however, Mr. Baehler voluntarily surrendered this option and sold the land for the benefit of the company for £220,00. For this gratifying result we owe our best thanks to Mr. Baebler, and a resolution to record our appreciation of his services will be proposed for your consideration. Of the proceeds of the sale of this surplus land referred to above we have still to receive £120,000, payable within 10 years. The receipt of this sum will reduce the book value of our freehold and leasehold land and buildings to under £100,000, while the actual value of about 63.000 metres of land retained for hotel purposes at Ghezireh is largely in excess of that figure, without taking our hotel buildings at Ghezireh and at Shepheard's into account at all. The profits for the year amount to £45,158 108 7d, and are supplemented by interest and transfer fees, which bring up the total credit to profit and loss account for the year to £46,530 0s. 10d, as compared with £10,088 17s 8d for the preceding year. From this sum has to be deducted the service of the debentures, amounting to £13,305 10s 10d, while the other financial charges, including £3,571 for the amortisation of the compensation paid to the Cie. Internationale des Grands Hotels, amount altogether to £4,131 9s 1d, making together £19,436 19s 11d, and leaving and net profit of £27,093 0s 11d, being £5,892 12s 11d more than last year. After three more years the charge of £2,571 per annum completely amortise the compensation referred to and relieve the charge to profit and loss account to a corresponding extent.
THE BALANCE SHEET

With regard to the balance sheet, I have already incidentally remarked on the account headed "freehold and leasehold land and buildings." The plant, fixtures and furniture have been added to by £2,647 6s, while very considerable sums have been spent on maintenance, amply sufficient to cover all depreciation. The item "goodwill" is gradually being reduced, a further sum of £732 being written off last year. The goodwill at the formation of the company represented the difference between the purchase price of the various properties and the valuation of the assets taken over by the company. The remaining assets call for no further comment beyond remarking that the cash balance of £118,967 2s 11d is larger than at any time in the history of the company. As regards the liabilities, the first mortgage debenture debt has been reduced during the year by £48,600, while the second debentures have been reduced by £100. Our general manager, Mr. Baebler, reports that the hotels have been maintained in good state of repair and efficiency out of revenue. The Board recognize and desire to express their appreciation of the valuable services of Mr. Baehler, to whose good management and foresight the present position of the company is largely due. They also heartily acknowledge the assistance of the resident directors in Cairo. I now beg to move 'That the directors' report and accounts for the year ending 30th April 1906, as submitted to the shareholders, be received and adopted."
Mr. J. J. Hug seconded the motion and it was carried unanimously.

The Chairman further moved, "That a dividend of 5 percent. on the preference shares and 17) percent on the ordinary shares of the company for the year ending 30th April, 1906, be and the same are hereby declared, "payable on and after Monday, and July, 1906."
Mr. E A. Harrison seconded this, and it was adopted.
Mr. Harrison moved the re-election of the retiring directors--Lord Claud Hamilton and Mr. J. J. Hug.
Mr. Peat seconded the motion, which was carried.
The Chairman briefly thanked the shareholders for this mark of confidence in his colleague and himself.
Oa the motion of Mr. Wright, seconded by Mr. Jacob, Messrs. Turgaand Younge and Co. were reappointed auditors.
THANKS VOTED TO MR. BABHLBR.

The Chairman: I will now move the resolution which I referred to in my opening remarks, and I am sure you will heartily endorse it-"That the shareholders desire to record their high appreciation of Mr. Charles Baebler's able management of the hotels and to tender him their best thanks of his option for the sale of surplus land at Ghezireh and the subsequent sale thereof for the benefit of the company."
Mr. Oppenheim seconded this vote and it was unanimously accorded.

Mr. Baebler proposed a vote of thanks to the Chairman and directors for their services, which was also seconded by Mr. Oppenheim and carried and a brief acknowledgment having been made by the Chairman, the proceedings terminated.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB
div.p: The following circular has been issued to the members :
The committee beg to inform you that, until the floating bath is completed, the members have been granted the use of the basin adjoining the Graving Dook at Gabbari.
The members are therefore requested to most every Saturday at 3 30 p.m., starting from the 7th inst.
If possible times of members will be taken and a handicap arranged for the 14th July, for one prize value P.T. 50.
Tram tickets may be obtained from the Hop. Secretary viz., 10 for P.T. 6.
Costumes are expected to arrive shortly. It is to be hoped that the members will turn up in strong force and introduce their friends.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit--within certain necessary limits free discussion.

div.head: TURKISH COAL
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir, I have read your yesterday's article under the above heading with interest and its allusion to the cheapness of the Asia Minor coal bus suggested to my mind whether this coal could not be exported to Alexandria, Port Said, and other Egyptian ports of bunker for ocean-going steamers. Would it not be cheaper and quicker to get part of our supplies from Turkey than from Newcastle or Cardiff. The pit's mouth price of the Zonguldagh coal is, I believe, about 10s. and the situation of the mines almost on the sea is of immense advantage. Of course, the coal cannot compete with Newcastle as regards quality, bat they mix very well. To, Heracles coalfield is of historic interest for it supplied all the British steamers engaged on the Crimean War, and the old locomotives and plant employed by the British are interesting relics of that time. The coal is not very popular with a certain section of the Levantine shipping community who have contracts with English collieries, but their objection is only natural. This notwithstanding there is no reason why the coal ould not be introduced and tried in Egypt I am of the opinion that it wald pay. Yours, etc.,

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES

div.p: A londres, le Consolidé anglaisa bausné do 1/8 a 17 7/8. L'Unifiée est rast se invariée à 101 8, de même que la National Bank 25 1/1, l'Agricole à 9 5/8, la Daina á 16 7/8 et la Delta Light à 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Bgyptiena glotats on reprise de 8 francs à 757. LA Badque d Athènes a réagi de 1 franc à 153.

Au début de la séance de ce matin, notre marché des valeurs a manifeste de bonnes dispositions. Ces velléités de reprise n'ont pa, natarellyment, se maintenir, et l'animation n'a pas tardé à faire place au calme babitael, ramenant plas (u moins les cours à leur niveau d'hier. La frute en est exolasivement à la saison morte, qui bat son plein. Certes la situation da narol est saine et la tendance zénérale raste relati rement ferme, mais il est difioile de modi fier snaiblement, pour l'instant, on ordre de chose déterminé par l'absence de spéculateurs, par le manque d'ordres aérieux.

La National Bank a progressé a 25 1/4-5/16: L'Agricole est restée à 9 9/16. Le Comptoir Finatoier a avancé . 6 1/8 3/16 l'action an dienn) et à 5 13/16 7/8 la nouvel e. L'estion Crédit Poncier, assez vnon vemantée, regigné 2 frases # 756.
L'action Immobilière met montée à 364 et la part de for dateur à 582 L'act on Allotment a avancé 31/1-5/16 et la part le fondateur à 107-108. Bien tende, l'U nion Poncière s'est insorita 6116.
L'action Brasserie des Pyramides a mollis 119-130 et la part de dividen le à 60. Les Cimets ont été traités à 67-68.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, 199 Nangoviob ont té délaissés à 15 7/16. Les Egyptian (Bael ler) ont encora gagné 1/16 à 5 7/16-1/2. Les ppar Ezypt ont été négocié à 4 7/16-1/2. Les plendid ont été cotés 38/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, le Delta Land ont its poussés jusqu'à 3 9/16 pour revenir 13 7 16 1/2. Las Hooker ont dobaté à 11/32 de co prix. Les Oasis ont ete ramenes a 1 1/15-3/32. les Markets à 26 ali. 6. et les salt and floda à 19 sh. 6. Les Walke: and Meimarachi se sont raffermis à £0 11/16.

Les actionnaires de l'Egyptiin Land and Genąral Trust Ltd. (Hooker) sont convoqués on a bemblée générale extraordinaire à Londres pour le jeudi 19 Juillet courant, à l'effet d'approarer la liquidation de la Booiété et sa fusiqa avec l'Egyptian Delta Lard and Invest mont Co., sur les bases que nous avons déj indiquées. Il est définitivement arrêté, on le sait, lue las actions da Trust seront échangées à raison de 6 (10 shellings versée) contre une aotiga de la Delta Land.
Vie Assemblée extraordinaire des actionnaire de la Delta Land Co, est convoquée le 19 Juillet pour le même objet.
Noas détachons d'one lettre de Londres, en date du 28 Juin, les lignes suivantes :

"L'abaissement da taox officiel de l'escompte n's pas produit an grand effet sur le marché. Au Stock Exchange, quelques efforts ont été Beqaisés pour y determiner un peu d'activité; mais les résultats en ont été faibles et éphé. mère. La Bourse s'abandonne à une réaction qui faise sa foroe dans la chute da Consolidé, dans la situation critique de la Bassie, dans la faiblesse des mines d'or et dans la mauvaise tenag de New York.

"Le Consolidé est assez malmené et, sous les osaps répétés de la baisse, le voici retombé au-dessous de 88 La sécurité de l'extrême négoela bilité que présente notre 2 1/4 pour cent ne affisent plus, parait-il, à fsire admettre, combio autrefois, le modeste reviou qu'il rap porte quand notre marché est encombré de valeurs beaucoup plus rémgnéra rices, offrant, en Bonme, peu d'alléas et souvent susceptibles de plus value. L'activité industrielle et com mero:ale a toujours pour conséquence d'éloigner les sympathies des titres à revenu fixe et con. damés à une immobilité plus ou moins absolae, jour les reporter vers les valeurs à revenu variable ou paraissant plus vivantes."
On annonce de Paris que la Société des Bacreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte fait pro véder à l'impression des obligations nouvelles. La remiga en sera faite pioshainement au détenteure.
Le premier coupon fixe intérimaire de Pro. 4 l'énéance da 1er Juillet 1906 sera payé an mom int de l'échange.
Nons n'avons pas en les cours du coton en Améliqae, les marchés étant restés fermés hier l'ogpasion de la fête de l'anniversaire da l'Iad pendance des Etats-Unis.

Le marché de Liverpjol etait en reprise de 4 à 5 points sur l'ancienne et la nouvelle récolte, "Ini le marché a olótaré ferme hier par gaita des chats de la spéculation. Le Juillet, qui avait fini à 18 31/32, a ouvert ce matin à 18 13/1pour olótarer à 18 27/32.

div.head: THE Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above Company will be held at Hall No. 43, Winchester Honse, Old Broad Street, in the City of London on Thursday, the 19th day of July 1906, at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit, passing the following Resolutions, or Resolofions to a similar effect. If Resolutions 1 to 9 inclusive should be passed by the requisite majority, they will be submitted for confirmation to a subsequent General Meeting to be hereafter convened so as to become Special Resolutions.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS
div.p: That the Memorandum and Articles of Association be varied as follows :

1. By striking out from Section 3, subsection (a) of the Memorandum of Association the words "in any district" and by substituting for the words "in which the Railways belonging to or that may at any time hereafter belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, or any extension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constructed or proposed to be constructed, may serve or be intended to serve" occurring in the same subsection the words "or in the Sudan."
2. That Article 75 of the Articles of Association of the Company be altered by striking out the words, commencing "and every exercise of the power" down to the end of that Article.
3. That Article 81 be altered by striking out the words "or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited."
4. That Article 85 be altered by striking out the words "provided that this prohibition shall not apply to any Contract dealing or transaction with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited."
5. That Article 86 be altered by striking out all words after the words "shall be vacant."
6. That Article 87 be altered by striking out the words "save as aforesaid" appearing in the first line of such Article

7. That Article 89 be struck out and that there be substituted therefor the following Article : "The remuneration of the Directors "shall be the sum of £250 per annum to "each of the Directors and £500 per "annum to the Chairman, and such "remuneration shall be deemed to accrue "de die in diem. The remuneration shall "be exclusive of the sums, if any, which "under the provisions of these Presents "Director on account of special services."
8. That Article 20 be altered by striking out the words "provided he be approved by the Board of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited."
9. That Article 96 be altered by striking out the words "one Director" and substituting therefor the words "two Directors."
10. That the Capital of the Company be increased from £250,000 to £500,000.

11. That the Memoradum of Agreement between the Company and the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, now submitted to the Meeting and initialled by the Chairman for the purposes of identification be approved and authorised to be entered into (subject to such alterations as the Board may think fit), and that the Board be authorised to enter into such further or other agreements as they may consider desirable for carrying such Memorandum of Agreement into effect.
By Order of the Board,
P.J. HORNE, Secretary

Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses, either at the Registered Office of the Company in London, two clear days before the Meeting, i.e., not later than the 16th July, or with the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, or Alexandria ten clear days before the date of the Meeting, i.e., not later than 7th July, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held.
Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, which must be produced by the holders attending the Meeting.

Copies of two circular letters issued to the Registered Shareholders with this Notice may be obtained upon application at the Offices of the Company, 211-214, Gresham House, Old Broad Street, London, E. C, or from the National Bank of Egypt, Caire or Alexandria, Egypt.

div.p: L'Administration des Télégraphes de l'Etat l'honneur de porter la connaissanoda Pablie qu'ave erreur s'est glimde dans l'avis publié à la date 14 Jain dernier concernant 80 postes vacants à l'Bools de Télégraphie. Dans l'avant dernier paragraphe il est dit que les é èves qui passeraient avec soods l'examen, seraient employés comme télégra phistes avec un traitement de L.B. 4 par mois. div.head: NATAL REBELLION. OUTRAGE BY REBELS. TROOPS FROM TRANSVAAL.

div.p: The operations against Mesini have had no definite result beyond the occupation of the rebel valley, the capture of cattle, and the destruction of kraals. Altogether 444 have been killed. The remains of a white man, murdered by the rebels, have been found, terribly mutilated. It is stated that the rebels wetted their assegais and dipped their fingers in his blood and smeared their lips with it. The troops are furious.
(Reuter)
The Bloemfontein and Harrismith troops and a portion of the Pretoria garrison, have been ordered to hold themselves in readiness to start for Natal.
(Reuter)

Mr. St. John Brodrick, in a letter to the Times," declares that the proposed wholesale reductions in the Army, and especially in the Artillery, would, if carried out, be a national calamity and would make the richest nation in the world a general laughing stock. The "Times" largely confirms the "Tribune" article of the 2nd inst. and strongly emphasizes the danger of reducing the military standard to that of 1872, while the national responsibilities have been immensely increased.
(Reuter)

div.head: EAST AFRICA PROTECTORATE. PREVENTING A LAND BOOM.

div.p: House of Commons.- Mr. Churchill stated that it was contrary to the policy of the Government to exclude any of His Majesty's subjects from mining, settling on, or acquiring land, but in view of the comparatively limited area of the East Africa Protectorate suitable to Europeans, reasonable discretion is exercised in dealing with applications for land.
(Reuter)
House of Commons- Fixed November 80 as the date for the stoppage of the recruitment of Chinese for the Transvaal.
(Reuter)
The Tsar has cashiered three leading officers in the mutinous Guards Regiment, including Prince Vassiltchikoff.
(Reuter)
The newspapers prominently publish the speech of Mr. Bryan, who will probably be the Democratic candidate in the presidential election.
(Reuter)

div.head: AUSTRIA AND SERVIA. TARIFF WAR BEGUN.

div.p: The temporary commercial arrangement between Austria and Servia ended yesterday, on Servia refusing to pledge herself to purchase guns from Austria. A tariff war has begun.
(Reuter)
The Ministry has resigned. Senor Lopez Dominguez will form a new Cabinet.
(Havas)
The Porte has refused to acknowledge the deposition of Vithynos at Samos.

div.head: BRITISH HOSPITAL AT JERUSALEM
div.p: His Royal Highness the Duke of Connaught presided last week, at 7, St. James's-square, by the kindness of Earl Egerton of Tatton, over a largely attended meeting, held with the sanction of his Majesty the King, in order to enlist farther pecuniary support for the British Ophthalmic Hospital at Jerusalem, belonging to the Grand Priory of the Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem in England. Among those who had accepted invitations to be present were the Archbishop of York, the Primate of New Zealand, Earl Egerton of Tatton, and the Duchess of Buckingham and Chandos, Viscount Knutsford, Lord St. Levan, the Dowager Lady Kensington, Lady Jephson, Lady Farley, Lady Seager Hunt, Sir Charles Murray, General Sir Richard Harrison, General Sir Charles Warren, Sir James Andrew Clark, Sir Dyce Duckworth, Mr. and Mrs. Israel Zangwill, Bir R. Douglas Powell, the Baroness De Knoop, Sir Edward and Lady O'Malley, and c.

His Royal Highness said he regretted that the Grand Prior was not able to be present, but having been asked by him to preside be did so gladly, in order that he might show the interest he took in an undertaking which he could honestly say was one of the finest things done in recent year. The Ophthalmic Hospital under the Order at Jerusalem was and had been doing a great work, and he thought a still greater work lay before it. But, like every other hospital, in order to carry it on efficiently,a sufficiency of money was essential. The hospital was opened in 1882, and the expenditure up to the period covered by the last annual report was £25,035 and it was a significant fact that the Sultan, as the hand of the Mahom fuedans, showed his confidence in this, an essentially Christian, institution, by presenting the freehold site, of the value of about £820, towards it. Since 1899, with one exception, the cost of maintenance and working expenses had exceeded the income, and the deficit now amounted to £5,527. This seemed a large amount, but speaking with some knowledge of hospitals at home, he thought none of them would be satisfied if they did not possess a good debt. (Laughter.) Therefore, the hospital at Jerusalem was not in a worse position than those at home, and it was in the fortunate position of having a reserve fund of £6,388 invested in trustees' securities. But owing to the increased work and the ever-increasing popularity of the hospital, owing chiefly to the skill of the medical staff and the absence of any attempt at proselytizing, it was found necessary to ask for support to the extent of £1,500 a year. Since 1886 the hospital bad thrown open its doors to 9,720 inpatients, and the number of beds had been increased from sixteen to Forty-two. The number of out-patients during the same period was 93,282, which involved 250,562 attendances, whilst no fewer than 18,786 operations had been performed. Many of those who had been in Eastern climates must have regretted to see the fearful ravages made by ophthalmia; if therefore, they, - Christian people, and, above all, a philanthropic English people, could do anything to mitigate this terrible curse, they were doing a great and noble work. (Cheers.)

General Sir Charles Warren moved, Mr. Israel Zangwill seconded, and Mr. Brudenell Carter supported a resolution recognizing the splendid work which was being done by the hospital, without distinction of creed or nationality, and affirming its worthiness of increased support. This having been adopted,
Earl Egerton of Tatton moved, and Lord Knutsford seconded, a vote of thanks to his Royal Highness for presiding, and the proceedings terminated after a brief acknowledgment.

div.head: THE POWERS AND ABYSSINIA.
div.p: Tłe "Petite République" points out that an essential factor of the forthcoming agreement concerning Abyssinia is the stipulation as to the maintenance of the status quo with the reciprocally binding clause that in case the status quo were disturbed none of the three Powers shall take any initiative without consulting the other. The other clauses stipulate for the establishment of the open door and equality of economic treatment for all nations, Germany having obtained early this year a treaty of commerce with Menelik, all the other nations should be placed on a footing of equality. This journal remarks that certain timorous temperaments in France have from fear of a "new Moroccan incident" been inclined to do nothing before consulting Germany. The writer points out how derogatory that would be to French dignity and how full of risks from the point of view of the Anglo-French entente. Moreover, no comparison can be drawn between the Moroccan and the Abyssinian questions, for in the latter case Germany has no longer the pretext of intervention on the ground of intended alteration of the status quo. In the impending Abyssinian Convention maintenance of the status quo is the very object of the agreement. "There are no longer, therefore, any reasons for beating about the bush."

div.head: BELLA VISTA HOTEL.
div.p: This excellent hotel, which includes also a hydropathic establishment is situated in the healthiest part of modern Jaffe, close to the sea, and commands and magnificent view of the old town. It supplies every home comfort, has a large salon and airy bedrooms, promenade, and a cuisine suited to all tastes. It is within easy walking distance of the station and quay, Moderate charges.

The Hydropathie Department, which is furnished with all necessary baths and electrical apparatus, is under the care of a skillful diplomed physician, whose efficacious treatments have already rendered invaluable help to many sufferers.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON SEED IN NATAL. SUCCESSFUL EXPERIMENTS.
div.p: A Natal correspondent of the "Manchester Guardian" says that an enterprising farmer has solved the problem of cotton growing in that colony, and Liverpool, it seems, may look out for 20 bales of some 260lb, each grown at Esperanza, on the south coast of Natal. Various difficulties, especially insect pests, have been overcome, and several varieties of cotton have been grown successfully. These are described as "American improved Uplands," "Russell's Big Boll," "East Coast Egyptian," "White Egyptian," and "Allen's improved Uplands." The correspondent speaks well of these, and some of them are unusually long in the staple. He continues: "From a commercial point of view the experiment is likely to be so successful as to lead to a very considerable extension of the cotton-growing movement in Natal. Mr. Kirkman intends to publish a full report of his account sales and costs. He has already succeeded in proving that insect pests ban be eradicated, or at any rate, controlled, and that the cotton plant will open its bolls - both hitherto debatable points. Moreover, the cost of fertilizing has not been very great, and the difficulty, or presumed difficulty, of picking, has been easily surmounted."

div.head: DEATH OF MR. BUDGET MEAKIN.
div.p: Mr. Budgett Meakin, the wall known authority on Moroccan affairs, died somewhat suddenly at Hampstead last week. Mr. Meakin, who was only 40 years of age, became assistant editor of "The Times of Morocco" at the age of 18; was subsequently editor, and held that post until 1893. Then began several years of travel and study of social questions in nearly every country of Europe, Asia, North America, and North Africa, the fruits of which were a series of lectures in England and America's and a number of books on Morocco, which have added much to our knowledge of the land of the Moors. Such books ware "The Moors," "The Land of the Moors," and "Life in Morocco." He was awarded the Order of the Medjidieh by the Sultan of Turkey for his studies of Islam in 1902 and 1904.

He was known as a lecturer on industrial and social problems, chiefly through his Shaftesbury Lectures on "Housing," He was instrumental in establishing the British Institute of Social Service, and at the time of his death he was interested in the formation of a Consumers' AntiSweating League

div.head: SLEEPING SICKNESS.
div.p: The King of the Belgians (the "British Medical Journal" states) has signed a decree establishing a prize of £8,000, to be awarded to anyone, regardless of nationality, who shall discover cure for sleeping sickness; and opening a credit of £12,000, to be allotted towards the furtherance of research as to the treatment and prophylaxis of the disease.
